canadian.text: Throw the baby out with the bath water.
Once the last tree is cut and the last river poisoned, you will find you cannot eat your money.
All Hallows moon, witches soon.
The devil places a pillow for a drunken man to fall upon.
Walk a mile in my moccasins to learn where they pinch.
Do not yell "dinner" until your knife is in the loaf.
You can’t catch skunks with mice.
Waste not want not.
Through other people’s faults, wise men correct their own.
A penny saved is a penny gained.
Don’t count your chickens before they hatch.
canadian.description: When you do something in preparation for another thing that may not even happen. For example, I am going to buy a dress, even though no one has invited me to the party.

canadian.text: All that glitters is not gold.
canadian.description: A regularly used proverb, this talks about things not being as good as they first appear. For example a person might dream about living in the huge mansion at the end of the street, but in reality the cost of running that mansion is a whole other set of problems, the house might look amazing but in truth it isn’t as great as it first appears.

canadian.text: Do not put all your eggs in one basket.
Don’t beat about the bush.
Look before you leap.
canadian.description: Make decisions carefully. Think about it first.

canadian.text: Don’t judge the book by the cover.
Pot calling the kettle black.
Patience is a tree whose root is bitter, but its fruit is very sweet.
Laugh all the way to the bank.
Once bitten. Twice shy.
When you talk about the sun, you will see her beams.
His bark is worse than his bite.
Easier said than done.
